comment_text: Here I am a decade later and still some of the best content on the internet..... So magic makes a helicopter fly?

I'm seeing a lot of confusion on the CH-47 (tandem rotor), Pusher prop, and regular helos. Being a former Coast Guard pilot I have thousands of hours of helo experience. ALL helos can pivot around any point in space. It just takes the pilot to make the appropriate control movements. It is called "low work". When I was teaching new pilots "turns on a spot" I would do a pivot around them so they could get a better sight picture but I could do a turn around the tail, the rotor shaft, myself, or any other point inside or outside the aircraft. With the more experienced pilots, we often had competitions. Being a left-hander it took me longer to learn until I was taken under the wing of another left-hander with many more hours. We made up all kinds of exercises to practice. Aircraft are made for right-handers. As mentioned on a regular helo you have the rotor system and a tail rotor so the tail rotor provides the turning force. On a CH-47 the rudder pedals are intermixed with the cyclic controls to change the angle of attack of the two rotor systems to provide a twisting moment. Again it is the skill of the pilot that makes the CH-47 pivot around any point in space though there are some standard maneuvers that the CH-47 pilots are trained to do, due to the size of the aircraft. Figure maneuvering something 100 feet long, actually, 98, which is the rotor paths tip to tip. Most houses are only 30 to 40 feet long. The transmissions of both rotors turn at the exact same RPM. The rotors can't hit each other even though they overlap each other. Now there is a vertical hinge on each blade that does allow a certain amount of lead and lag but this is restricted to prevent interference. This allows for weight and airflow imbalances. The horizontal hinge allows the blades to move up and down and the blades are only held in position by centrifugal force. The rotor plane cones when power (angle of attack) is applied. When the rotors get below a certain rpm the droop stops flip in to prevent the rotors from dropping and hitting the aircraft or ground. The tilt in the forward rotor allows the aircraft to fly more level in forward flight, therefore, being more aerodynamic plus the rotors being on two different levels minimizes the interference from the tail rotor blades going through the airflow of the forward rotors. Now with retreating blade stall on the CH-47, yes you can push it but you will lose lift and also cause flutter. CH-47 rotor blades are not solid and are actually bonded (glued) together. If you get too much flutter, they will crack and break. In the operational flight manual for the CH-47 (available online), there are airspeed limitations mainly due to density altitude, gross weight, and rotor blade compression but also the configuration of the aircraft. All helos have them. Now pusher prop aircraft usually have stub wings to take some of the lift requirement off of the rotor system so the blades don't stall as their angle of attack is less. A greater angle of attack is what causes the retreating blade to stall. I hope this helps.

So many things incorrect in his description...first, rotor blades on US helicopters spin counter clockwise, putting the retreating blade on the left. It doesn't change much else until you run out of power and need to know what pedal to push, or not push. Next, increasing pitch does not counter act dysemitry of lift, it actually creates more speed, which causes dysemitry of lift. The advancing blade flaps up, decreasing the angle of attack and lift. On the retreating blade, the blade flaps down, increasing the angle of attack which helps balance the two sides out. This is what only works up to a certain point. It is NOT a self correcting problem. The helicopter will pitch up and roll left, potentially crashing the aircraft. The stall region around the rotor hub builds and moves left. It starts on the inside because the inside of the blade is moving slower than the tip. As airspeed increases, the stall region gets bigger. Because of dysemitry of lift, you will never get close to getting blade speed to mach, which can "cause bad things to happen". But yes, the Chinook IS the fastest, because it doesn't suffer from retreating blade stall as much because of the tandem rotor.

I was right, you are incorrect, it is just a phase lag from max pitch input to max coning angle (max control portion). Also, the blades are NOT FIXED to the chopper, they are free to move vertically and horizontally to a limited degree:
PHASE LAG
The advancing blade will encounter its highest rotational speed 90° prior to a position over the nose of the aircraft, but does not experience the highest degree of flapping at this point (figure 3-19). In fact, this maximum flapping occurs over the nose, 90° later, due to a principle of a dynamic system in resonance. A system in resonance receives a periodic excitation force sympathetic with the natural frequency of the system. The flapping frequency of a centrally hinged system is equal to the speed of rotation. Therefore, maximum response occurs 90° after maximum periodic excitation. This is termed phase lag. In order for a helicopter in forward flight to roll into a left turn, maximum lift must be realized at the right "wing" position and minimum lift must be realized at the left "wing" position. Therefore, maximum AOA must occur at the 180° position and minimum AOA must occur at the 360° position. To obtain the appropriate response 90° after maximum excitation, logic tells us forward cyclic is the appropriate input to initiate a left turn. No wonder helicopters are such a challenge to fly! Well, they are challenging, but not for this reason. Inputs are translated 90° prior mechanically, thanks to some design engineers who had a little foresight.

I believe you are mistaken about gyroscopic recession.  Gyroscopic recession is the cone described by the vertical axis of a spinning object most severely as the spin decays.  You can see it when the bottom of the axis begins to describe a circle on the surfact which supports it.  In aircraft, recession is a bad thing, and a lot of technology has gone into solving the problem.  However, gyroscopic displacement--the term you should have used--is a good thing and is what makes a gyro stable.  Displacement occurs when the force applied is realized exactly 90-degrees in the direction of the turn of the object, or, in the case of a helo, the rotor disc.  When the retreating blade loses lift, that loss (on the right side looking down) is realized at the tail thereby lifting the nose.  You described the effect but used the wrong term.  All helo control forces are applied 90-degrees from where you want the force be realized.  To make a rotor disc bank right, lift must be applied to the tail.

In propeller airplanes, we call it assymetrical disc loading.  When an airplane climbs its flight path is not in the direction it is pointing but lower.  The centerline of thrust shifts to the right side of the propeller, no longer in the center.  It's one of the factors that causes a left turning tendency in airplanes when they climb so right rudder is used to correct it.

Retreating blade stall is self correcting?  Sorry no.......It's not always but can be deadly.  Retreating blade stall causes several things to happen.  The advancing blade can go supersonic at the tips and the retreating blade doesn't have enough blade speed relative to the wind to make enough lift on that side and due to gyroscopic procession it will pitch up and to the opposite direction of rotation.  I the blades turn clockwise it turns right and if the turn CCW it will turn left.  But the high pitch on the retreating side causes the blades to twist and it can cause them to cone down cutting off the tailboom.  It is NOT self correcting.  You MUST lower the collective and do NOT fight the pitch up.  It can easily get into an un-recoverable situation.

This is only one type of helicopter, and so is not accurate.  There are new coaxial helicopters that use two stiff contra-rotating blades.   Because they are so stiff, they basically act as wings.   And because they are going opposite directions, they cancel each other out and so there's no bias to lift.     Likewise, they are using a traditional airplane like propeller for forward thrust, and thus don't have to "lean in" to go forward fast, which is far more aerodynamic as well.    Check out the Sikorsky S-97.  Its not designed exclusively for speed, and yet is expected to go around 280mph.

Why not just use contra-rotating blades on the same axis? Like a Tu-95 Bear, but only for a helicopter. That way, one blade's asymmetric thrust would counter the other's, meaning you wouldn't have to worry about stalling the downwind side so much.

My idea is this (I am not sure at all if it makes sense): The Chinook is faster because it has to helixes that are counter-routating. This allows the helicopter to have the front side that is asymmetrically lifting, but the back side compensating for that by asimmetrically lifting in the other direction (left or right). This way, maybe, one can reach higher speeds because if the helicopter reaches that critical "lower" speed at which a regular one rotor helicopter would stall (and its front side would turn upwards, as said in the video), in this case the helixes would counter-act against each other and keep the helicopter from stalling by canceling out the angular momentum and keeping the helicopter stable. I know this video is years old, but I was wondering something.
Would smaller rotors provide faster speeds?
If you had a helicopter with a rotor of 20ft diameter, the tips would hit 62800fpm at 1000rpm, and the sound barrier is 67500fpm; which is fairly close.
But let's say you had a second helicopter, with multiple rotors of 10ft diameter, the tips would hit 31400fpm at 1000rpm; or the same 62800fpm at 2000rpm.
Since a rotor of half diameter is two times faster, why do we not see more aircraft with substantially smaller rotors but many more of those smaller rotors?
The Blackhawk has a rotor diameter of 53' 8", and if we sized the rotors down to 10', and compensated for power loss with additional rotors, would the blackhawk not be able to go over 5 times faster if everything was based on rotor size alone?
Also, I haven't watched the other videos, so this is the only factor I have knowledge on.

"to counteract this, the rotor on the retreating side is given more pitch to produce more lift"

My understanding is the rotor on the retreating side is mainly given a downwards velocity (flapping hinge) while the rotor on the advancing side is given an upwards velocity (flapping hinge) to change the angle of attack (relative pitch) to equalize the lift. This has implications for how the cyclic controls the helicopter through phase lag more than gyroscopic precession - tilting the rotor disc with equal lift on all blades, instead of having more lift on one side and transmitting a moment to the hub through rigid blade roots. The hub has flapping hinges which prevent the transmission of rolling/pitching moments from the blade roots, so we can induce roll/pitch or correct for it by tilting the rotor disc to change the thrust line about the center of mass, instead of transmitting moments from the blade roots to the mast.

I didn't see or may have missed in your helicopter videos, but another thing not allowed in most helicopters is inverted flight. (No loops or barrel rolls.)  This is because the main rotors flex and when upside down they will flex "up" into the body of the helicopter up there, perhaps knocking off part of the tail, or shattering the rotor, or both.  You can do chandells and hammerhead stalls, however, or a modified version if you minimize the time in 0 G and at least keep positive pitch on the rotor.  We used to so them in VietNam in Hueys, LOHs, or OH58s (Bell Jet Rangers).

The Chinook is the fastest--so fast, in fact, that it needs to SLOW DOWN for Apaches and Blackhawks during escort missions in combat operations (I know because I was deployed in OEF 10 in Afghanistan.  :) ).  The reason why the Chinook is the fastest is actually quite simple:  Double the rotors means double the propulsion.  Not to mention, the Chinook has the largest rotors and engines in it's class of VTOL aircraft.


Plus, you see the forward blades on the Chinook?  How the forward rotor is more level then the rear one?  This is what allows the Chinook to counter-act a retreating blade stall--to the point where the forward rotor can be almost entirely devoted to keeping the chopper level (and thus, keep it from going into a retreating blade stall) while simultaneously allowing the rear rotor to be entirely devoted to forward motion.  Making the Chinook one of the fastest helicopters in existence.


Another interesting fact:  The reason why the Chinook doesn't need a tail-rotor to provide the counter-torgue, is because both of the rotors are spinning in opposite directions of eachother--one clockwise, the other counter-clockwise.  Thus, creating the counter-torque needed to keep the bird flying straight.  The Chinook actually turns (or controls it's yaw) by adjusting the speed at which the front or rear rotor spins!

2 things.
1) the helicopter will not only pitch back but will also roll towards the retreating blades. "Retreating blade stall is a major factor in limiting a helicopter’s never-exceed speed (V NE) and its development can be felt by a low frequency vibration, pitching up of the nose, and a roll in the direction of the retreating blade"
2) Its not self correcting the pilot does need to take steps to correct the problem before it becomes more severe."When recovering from a retreating blade stall condition, moving the cyclic aft only worsens the stall as aft cyclic produces a flare effect, thus increasing the AOA. Pushing forward on the cyclic also deepens the stall as the AOA on the retreating blade is increased. Correct recovery from retreating
blade stall requires the collective to be lowered first, which reduces blade angles and thus AOA. Aft cyclic can then be used to slow the helicopter."
http://www.faa.gov/regulations_policies/handbooks_manuals/aviation/helicopter_flying_handbook/media/hfh_ch11.pdf

Bladd tip speed is the same at a hover... Forward speed flight at 100 knots, add 100 kts to the advancing and subract 100 kts to the retreating blade... The aircraft now has a 200 knot difference in blade tip speed... The swash plate decreases lift or angle of attack on the advancing blade while increasing pitch or angle-of-attack on the retreating blade... An airfoil, whether it be fixed wing or rotor wing, starts to loose lift at about 18 to 20 dregrees to relative wind, thus entering retreating blade stall... The aircraft starts to get weak (as in starting to stall) on that side... and "fall off"... This can be experienced in Summer when flying at or close to Vne (Velocity never exceed) low level, over a forrested area and coming, suddenly, to a warm field (hot air raising) and entering Retreating Blade Stall Envelope.... You'll do that about ONCE in your lifetime..... This bit of wisdom comes courtesy of US Army flight school at Ft Wolters, TX many, many, many years ago... and with about 20, 000 hours of trying to stay alive... @CygnusX250 Yes and no. No matter how short you make the blades, the retreating blade still is going the opposite direction, and when you subtract the airspeed, you still end up in trouble, capping the speed under 250mph if I remember correctly. To solve this, they add wings ala Hind, Apache, and most recently, the Eurocopter X3. These wings aren't just for weapons or motors, but are lifting surfaces which take load off of the retreating blade, delaying the stall of the retreating side, giving you a higher speed before you get into trouble.

To make most helicopters quieter, they add more blades. Many PD's use the MD500 because it is about as loud as a minivan without a muffler (also note no tail rotor: it uses the exhaust from the engine to counter the rotor torque).

To further quiet the tip noise, the cormorant helicopter has funky blade tips which stabilize the air so the following blade has smoother air to fly through. It's very quiet for it's size.

So when the pilot gives an input and changes the pitch, the swash plate tilts which will push or pull one or more of the PCLs up or down. In the apache the swash plate is two piece rotating and non-rotating with the rotating section on top. The non-rotating section holds the pitch angle as the rotating spins on top pulling and pushing the PCLs up and down. If tilted to the left the blade starts to go down at the nose at 0*, is lowest at 270* and starts to rise and is back to neutral at 180*.

Apache mechanic here, it is done mechanically with the swashplate, though it is a bit different than the helicopter here because the apache has a semi-articulating main rotor. But back to your question. The pitch of the blades is controlled by the swash plate through pitch control links (PC Links) which control the pitch of the blades. This means that the swash plate and the blades all rotate together and do not change position  in relation to each other. continued in next comment.
Mechanically, with the swashplate. It's an adjustable cam system (check wikipedia article /Cam). Also the earlier video: /watch?v=q1Ivcj9rlGY

I think he's explained it a bit weirdly. What actually happens is that the blades flap up and down. It's not "controlled" by the helo or the rotorhead, it just happens naturally. The down flap on the retreating blade increases the AoA, the up flap on the advancing blade decreases the AoA such that the lift produced by both is the same. He said it's pitch is varied, but it's not. If you cyclicly alter the pitch as he described the rotor will tilt forward. That doesn't happen.

I know it's complex, but saying the pitch is increased on the retreating blade is misleading. yes, due to flapping the pitch increases, but the way you said it implies it's pitched up on the retreating blade side. That would just tilt the disk up at the back. Simple explaination good, wrong explaination, bad.

But the blades rotate in opposite directions, compensating for dissymmetry of lift by having their leading edges on opposite sides

All that cancels out is torque, that's why it doesn't have some other anti-torque system, like a tail rotor. Tandom rotor systems, also along with coaxial and intermeshing systems, still experience dissymmetry of lift. That has to do with the rotor disc as a whole and how unequal airspeeds cause unequal lift on the advancing and retreating halves of the rotor disc.

If a helicopter's main rotor blades spin too fast, it puts a lot of stress on the parts that hold that blade onto the rotor hub. There's little more that goes into how fast the blades can spin ( The engine driving the rotor system or, in the event of an engine failure, just the upward flow of air). An airplane's never exceed speed, whether it is a turbine or reciprocating engine, is based on structural integrity of the airframe itself.

Picture a ball on a string. Spin the ball around horizontally.  The ball will be traveling in a horizontal plane.  At some point, hit the ball downward.  At the instant of impact, you change the velocity (it's no longer moving horizontally), but not the location.  As the ball whirls, it will keep moving in a plane, but the plane is now tilted around the point of impact.  It will be lowest 90° later, highest 270° later, and will pass through the same point of impact.  Thus, gyroscopic precession.

The chinook is the fastest because it is a tandem-rotor configuration.  There is less of an issue with retreating blade stall, since the forward-going blade on each rotor is on opposite sides, thus reducing the need to increase pitch on the backward-going blade to counter the reduced lift.

So, as the rotor accelerates upwards (or downwards) through a given frame-rate multiple, we will see it go through the appearance of moving faster as it accelerates, a brief period where it appears to stop, and then it appears to move backwards again, appears to stop, and then appears to move forward again (repeating the cycle). This is easiest to see with controlled frame rates and RPM's of the wheel, although our eyes are also capable of this illusion on their own as well (eye is 20-60fps)

As others have replied, definitely an optical illusion. Combine this also with a relatively stable camera frame-rate and you can make a rotating wheel appear to stand still. For example, if a camera films at 30 fps, and your wheel is rotating at 30 rps (or a multiple) (1800 RPM, a moderate speed), then anybody watching that film will see it completely stop :) If your wheel is slightly faster (1900 RPM), it will look like it is slow-mo forward; 1700 RPM, and slow-mo backwards :)

Think tangential velocity, not angular. The Apache may have the fastest spinning rotor, but it also has the smallest, so this spin speed isn't converted to so much tangential speed as the larger rotors. The maths works out something like this:
omega=2*pi*rpm/60=tangential velocity in radians per second (rad/s)
Vtheta=omega*r=tangential velocity in metres per second (m/s)

Assuming a(speed of sound)=340m/s at STP - work out maximum blade sub sonic speed for all choppers in m/s and you will see.

Generally speaking, if you can make the rotor blade withstand the extra stresses and fatigue effects of a transonic shock wave, the shock stall it induces will more than likely counteract the lift imbalance you get, however that means you will eventually need both blades to go supersonic in order to maintain a significant delta v for at least some lift on the retreating blade.

It has more to do with tangential velocity than angular velocity (i.e. the speed of the blade tip, not how fast the whole thing is going). In this way, a greater rotor span means that a smaller angular velocity produces a greater tangential velocity, so even when it's spinning slower - it probably can't reach the highest speed with bigger blades.

I think the best answer here has to do with power management and governing.  Most helicopters have a governer which automatically adjusts engine rmp to maintain constant rotor rmp.  If rotor rmp varied then lift would greatly vary.  In order to maintain controlled flight you need to be able to vary lift as required and not power.  Other key issue to address is power management.  You only have so much power and some of it needs to be kept in reserve to bail your but out of trouble if need be.

What? It has to do with the frame-rate of the eyes. Or our brains to be more specific. When the rotational speed of the rotating object is equal (or a multiple) to the frame rate of our brain at that moment, it will appear to be frozen (so if one, two, three... revolution(s) takes as much time as the time taken between two frames) . When it passes that point and starts rotating faster it will seem to start rotating in the other direction.

Outdoors you can observe this effect if you are in the right place: View the wheel of a car as it drives by while there is a picket fence in between it and you. Also try viewing a car's spinning wheel or ceiling fan etc while blowing a raspberry! (blowing through loose lips to get them to flap, not blowing on an actual raspberry ;)

I picked the Chinook because the 2 rotors spin in opposite direction.

When the aircraft is more heavily loaded, this will be less effective since there is less lift to spare.

Because it has counter-rotating Rotors, there is always a forward traveling blade on each side, which eliminates the problem of lift dissymmetry (remember that the forward moving blade produces more lift), which, as Destin explained, is the most limiting factor for speed.

You are correct, counter rotating blades eliminate lift dissymmetry, which is the most limiting speed factor.  This still leaves rotor flutter, and rotor Maximum Mach as limiting factors, but in a counter rotating design, these can be corrected by stiff composite materials and rotor braking (slowing the rotor as the helicopter increases velocity to prevent mach shockwave at the blade tips).  Together, these have allowed Sikorsky's X2 to reach 250 Kts.
